metadata.title: Influence of nitrogen content of a new aluminophosphate oxynitride catalyst: A1PON in Knoevenagel condensation

ELSEVIER Applied Catalysis A: General 114 (1994) L191 L196 Letter Influence of nitrogen content of a new aluminophosphate oxynitride catalyst: AIPON in Knoevenagel condensation Paul Granges, Philippe Bastiansa, Roland Conanecb, Roger Marchandb, Yves Laurentb 'Unit de Catalyse et Chimie des Mat riaux Divis s, Universit Catholique Louvain, Place Croix du Sud 2/17, 1348 Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium 'Laboratoire de Chimie s Mat riaux, URA 1496 CNRS "Verres et C ramiques ", Universit de Rennes 1, Campus Beaulieu, 35042 Rennes C dex, Prance (Received 1 April 1994; revised 13 April 1994; accepted 13 April 1994) Abstract A new high surface area solid basic catalyst with tunable acid-base properties has recently been proposed [R. Marchand, R. Conanec, Y. Laurent, Ph. Bastians, P. Grange, L.M. Gandia, M. Mottles, J. Fernandes and 1. Odriozola, patent application FR 9401081; R. Conanec, R. Marchand, Y. Laurent, Ph. Bastians and P. Grange, in Soft Chemistry Routes to New Materials, Nantes, France, in press; P. Grange, Ph. Bastians, R. Conanec, R. Marchand and Y. Laurent, Chem. Commun., submitted for publication]. Starting from aluminophosphate (AIP04) oxide precursor and with careful adjustment of the nitridation procedure, it is possible to modify the global composition, changing the O/N content of the nitrided aluminophosphate (AIPON). This letter evidences that conversion in the malononitrilebenzaldehyde condensation largely depends on the O/N ratio of these new catalysts. Such basic solids are compared with conventional MgO catalyst. Keywords: Aluminophosphate oxynitride; Basicity; Knoevenagel condensation; Malononitrile benzaldehyde condensation; Nitridation; Nitrogen content; Surface area 1. Introduction The preparation of solid base catalysts is receiving much attention [ 1-8], since they may be used in the synthesis of fine chemicals and partially solve some environmental problems. Up to now, most of the studies have been devoted to the development of oxide based systems. However, recently, nor et al. [ 9-11 ] and Lednor [ 12] have reported the first results on non-oxide catalytic systems, namely 0926-860X/94/$07.00 1994 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved conrnn'1c ocnv inA Innnnl -r L192 P. Grange et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 114 (1994) L191-L196 silicone nitride or carbide. On the other hand, high surface area molybdenum nitride has been prepared and studied as catalyst for ammonia synthesis, ethane hydrolysis, hydrodesulphurization, hydrodenitrogenation, hydrogenation and ammonolysis [ 13-20 ] . Starting from ceramic developments [ 21-24 ] , we synthesized high surface area oxynitride aluminophosphate presenting strong basic properties from stoichiometric AIP04 (Al/P=1) activated at high temperature. Several nitrogen containing aluminophosphates were tested in Knoevenagel condensation. 2. Experimental 2.1. Materials The aluminium phosphate precursor (A 4) was prepared following the method proposed by Kearby [ 25 ] , starting from AIC13, 6H20 and H3P04 in alcoholic solution at low temperature. After washing, drying and final calcination at 800 C, this sol-gel method gives an oxide with 225 M2g-'. Nitridation of the aluminophosphate is performed under ammonia flow up to 800 C for different times. The characteristics of the precursors and the final oxynitrides (AIPON) are reported in Table 1. The chemical analysis of nitrogen is based on the reaction of the nitride ion N3- with a strong base and the formation of ammonia which is titrated. As the oxynitrides are refractory materials, the oxynitrides are attacked at high temperature with melted potassium hydroxide [ 26 ] . 2.2. Reaction procedure The liquid phase reaction is run in a stirred reactor. An equimolar solution of benzaldehyde and malononitrile (4 mmol) with toluene as solvent (30 ml) is magnetically stirred while heating up to 50 C. Then the powder catalyst (0.05 g) is added. Liquid samples of the suspension are taken every 30 min at the beginning Table 1 Chemical composition and specific surface area of oxides and oxynitride Oxynitride Composition Calcination Surface Composition Nitridation Nitridation N Surface temperature area temperature time (%) area ( C) m2 g-' ( C) (h) AIP04 800 225 AIP03.58Na.28 800 2 3.3 220 800 225 AIP03.0,No.66 750 15 8 195 800 225 AlPOZ. N,.o4 800 5 + 8 13 205 800 225 AIPO,.72N,.52 800 70 20 210 P. Grange et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 114 (1994) L191-Ll96 L193 of the reaction and then every hour, by a filtering syringe and analyzed by gas chromatography using a capillary column (CP Sil 8CB). 3. Results and discussion The conversion at different reaction times is illustrated in Fig. 1. For comparison, the conversion of a commercial MgO catalyst is also reported in the. figure. The first observation is that under the experimental conditions, only the Knoevenagel condensation occurs (Eq. 1). CHO Cr + CN Ph CN H CN CN No further reaction following a Michael-type addition is observed. g 100 C O '0 80 v C t~ 60 40 [1 ] y 180 240 Time (min) 60 7e-4 ~.8 8 ono 4e-4 3e-4 2e-0 6e-4 Se-4 le-0 Oe+O %N 1,3% %N=8% B %N=13% O %N % Fig. 1. Conversion vs. time of reaction. 3,3 8 13 20 Fig. 2. Rate of reaction in function of nitrogen content. eYo N L194 P. Grange et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 114 (1994) L191-L1 The second observation is that the rate of reaction and the amount of conversion largely depend on the nitrogen content of the catalyst. Fig. 2 illustrates the reaction rate as a function of the nitrogen content. There is no direct relationship between the O/N ratio and the catalytic conversion, since the temperature and time of nitridation as well as the calcination temperature of the precursor influence the final composition of the oxynitride [ 27 ] and therefore its surface properties. The third observation is that, even with reference to the same surface area, the catalyst with the highest nitrogen content is more active than pure MgO. The conversion /surface area of the best AI N as compared to pure MgO are 0.45 and 0.25, respectively. Using zeolites with basic sites, in particular NaGeX, NaSiX, Cs-Y or CsX [ 28,29 ] or hydrotalcites [ 30] , the following four-step reaction pathway in such a Knoevenagel condensation was proposed. step 1 NC-CHZ-CN + step 2 step 3 step 4 NC-CH-CN + BH CHO NC-CH-CN + m~ NC- ~ H-CH K'2 CN ' Ho CN NC- 2- _ off \ K3 \ NC- C-CH- I r NC- C=CH- I + OH l N ~ K-3 CN BH + OH' .~ B' + H20 On zeolite based catalysts [27,28] both first order or second order models fit with the results. This means that it is not possible to discriminate the limiting steps, which are either the proton abstraction by the basic site ( step 1) or the addition of the carbonyl group of the benzaldehyde on the stabilized anion ( steps 2 and 3 ) produced during the first step. On the present A N basic catalyst, the second order model undoubtedly fits with the experimental results. This indicates that it is the second step which is the limiting step in the reaction. P. Grange et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 114 (1994) 6191 L196 L195 4. Conclusion Starting from high surface area oxide aluminophosphate and after ammonia activation at high temperature, it is possible to prepare high surface area oxynitride aluminophosphate: A N. The nitrogen content may be controlled by the activation procedure. The nitrogen content largely controls the basic character of these catalysts and then their reactivity. Such solids are active and selective for condensation reactions (Knoevenagel reaction). The addition of the carbonyl group of the benzaldehyde to the enolate anion formed during the first step of the reaction by the basic site should be the limiting step.
